reviews.review_msg: I would not recommend. Lectures seem unconnected to what he tests. Assignments are quite different from tests. Incredibly boring lectures. The textbook assigned was old and boring. I ended up just self studying the Rosen Discrete math textbook. 1 out of maybe 10 lectures he will say something useful.

His notes were disorganized and made no sense. Avoid this professor at all times. I got advice from others that he was a prof to avoid, and I thought if I worked hard in this course, I could still do it. Oh i was so wrong. It doesn't matter how much effort you put into this course. His exams and assignments had no resemblance to notes whatsoever.

His lectures are monotone, the notes he writes are useless after looking back on them a few days later. His choice in examples used in lectures are often complicated, and he would often scratch out things after second guessing himself (he changed his solution 6 times once in class). MACM is already a difficult subject, even tougher with him.

worst teacher ever. got good marks in assignment and close to average in midterm. but failed final exam but few marks which gave me D. However, the class is curved. If i calculate my marks, I should get at least C- but this guy gave me D(after curved). Does not revealed how he curved it. He cannot even teach and youtube will save you.

All the lecture notes were hand written and only formula without any explanation. Only thing he did in class was just reading that hand written notes that he wrote previously without any explanation when to use this formula. All the exam questions were not even close to the textbook practice question. Maybe cause i am CMNS major

Class is established to be curved from day one. Lectures cover both theory and code, but you need to investigate the code base on your own to get a high mark. Tom listened to the suggestions, so the project work load has been reduced and you can also work in pairs. It's hard to do compilers justice in the span of 3 months, so he did a great job.

Lots of work for the compiler project but mostly due to trying to understand the code and trial and error. Apparently project has been made easier than prev years. Prof spent lectures at start of the term going over how to do certain parts of the project which was helpful to get started. Pretty accessible outside class for help. Lectures were ok.

(Fall 2023)

Tbh: avoid. Dry lectures with no recorded lectures for review, and no pre-posted slides. You'll need to rely on the textbook and the scanned lect. notes. Def read ahead in the textbook before lectures and hope you get a good TA to help explain things. Midterm and final averages were both low 50s, so take that as you will. Good luck!

Course is no joke - 2 courses worth of workload packed into 1. And it's already been watered down by a LOT.
Project is not dreadfully difficult as myth suggests - just a lot of trial and error + having to understand the codebase = very time consuming. Prof is knowledgeable and always available. Lectures are meh. You will come out a better dev.

MACM ON STEROIDS FOR NO REASON
Reasons why you should avoid this prof at all costs:
1. Be ready to self teach. f* his lectures of hand written notes and stick to the textbook
2. You will be confused. The assignments introduce concepts that are taught later down the road and some are not based on the lectures
3. The curve will be your only hope GLHF

This man is built like Santa Claus would not be surprise if his side hustle was the Santa in the mall but the difference from him and Santa is that Shermer is a walking L. Buddy is teaching half of MACM 201 and the homework has things we did not cover. The only gift he gives is he curves the marks. Please avoid this robot at all cost.
Half the time I had no clue what his ramblings where even about. Barely gave coherent examples in the lectures. Get ready to read like you never read before if you're taking macm101 with Shermy

You'll probably end up self-learning all the materials; attending his lectures won't help. His notes don't make much sense when you read it on your own, and since his lectures aren't recorded, then you're left puzzled when reading them. Assignments are vague, even the TAs couldn't do some questions; they would provide solutions copied from online.

He did 2 hour lectures and 1 hour problem sessions. Lectures were hard to follow as they were very dense and mathematical. I often found myself not fully understanding one point then being lost for the rest of the lecture. Definitely a class where you rely heavily on the textbook. Posts lecture slides but no recordings or problem solutions.

Fairly low workload, but very challenging with Shermer. He doesn't teach anything so your best bet is to read all the textbook sections he says the exams will be on and do as many textbook problems as you can. Everyone does pretty poorly objectively, but the course is graded on a curve so you pretty much just have to outperform your peers.

Brutal course with horrible prof, impossible to tell what exam questions will be like because Shermer provides no practice exams. Exams are are extremely difficult and just understanding algorithms is not enough. Workload is fair with only 4 assignments, but content is very challenging. Course is 100% self-study as lectures are useless.

He just read his PowerPoint in all the lectures. This course will definitely be useless in my future life. It is extremely bad. This is the worst class I have ever taken. I really want to give him a 0 rate. I WILL NEVER TAKE ANY COURSES TAUGHT BY THIS PROF.

This prof is very unorganized, there is miscommunication between the prof and the TA's, we didn't get our first assignment until a month and a half into the semester. Shermer just reads off the slides and barely shows any coding. Avoid this prof if you actually want to learn something in this course.

He tried to make lectures online, but he speaks a normal talking speed if you speed up the video to x2. That is if you watch the lectures at all. They do NOT explain any of the material, they are an introduction to SOME important subjects, and don't clarify anything. His office hours are him saying re-read the chapters.
We're a month into the semester and so far he has been quite bad at conveying the material in my opinion and also the way he speaks puts you to sleep. His notes are also quite bad.

Take this class if it's your only class, his lectures leave you brittle like glass. Enters the room with a coke, always has his notes hidden behind a cloak. Learn to write fast, or you'll forget everything like it's in the past. Focus on his assignments, work til you need a back alignment. I passed but I still dislike his teaching like Comcast.

Tom is a strong believer that the best way to learn how something works is by implementing it. In this course, we started with a setPixel() method, and ended it with an implementation of a 3D model renderer (subset of .obj files) and a graphics specification language for composing scenes. It was a lot of work, but was well worth it.

Start project early - it's a lot of work. Project is built upon throughout the semester and applies what you learned in class. Lectures can get confusing but the application of the concepts to the project helps. Don't be afraid to ask Tom for help when you get stuck, he's really kind. Final project is pretty cool. Not OpenGL based.
Try to avoid his class, assignments and exams were hard and he curves down the marks!!!!   The most boring class and worst prof I have ever had.

You won't learn much theories about compilers, but will totally strengthen your programming. So, if you don't "die" for programming, never think about this course. The worst thing is that he doesn't clarify how to do his assignments, you have to ask him by email or in office hours.

Made a difficult course even harder. He would go through long examples but would sometimes be unable to finish it or explain a theorem(from another chapter entirely!) needed to finish it. Notes are unclear and disorganized, sit at the front to see the notes and to hear him. Last day of class he covered two remaining chapters, badly.

I did not have a problem with his teaching. It was straightforward and he taught you what you needed to know for the assignments and exams. Unfortunately, his TA for the semester was totally useless. The assignments were hefty though, so for this class, make sure you start right away, because you will be doing coding all-nighters anyways.
